title: Jason Saab
text:
Jason Saab (born 8 October 2000) is an Australian professional <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> <a href="footballer">footballer</a> who plays as a er for the <a href="Manly-Warringah%20Sea%20Eagles">Manly-Warringah Sea Eagles</a> in the <a href="National%20Rugby%20League">NRL</a>.
He previously played for the <a href="St.%20George%20Illawarra%20Dragons">St. George Illawarra Dragons</a> in the <a href="National%20Rugby%20League">National Rugby League</a>.
Background.
Saab was born in <a href="Newtown%2C%20New%20South%20Wales">Newtown, New South Wales</a>, and is of <a href="Nigerians">Nigerian</a> and <a href="Indigenous%20Australians">Indigenous Australian</a> descent. Saab's step-father is <a href="Lebanese%20people">Lebanese</a>, hence his surname.
He played his junior rugby league for the <a href="Merrylands%20Rams">Merrylands Rams</a> in the <a href="Parramatta%20Junior%20Rugby%20League">Parramatta Rugby League</a>.
Saab attended <a href="Westfields%20Sports%20High%20School">Westfields Sports High School</a>.
Career.
2019.
Saab made his first grade debut in Round 19 of the <a href="2019%20NRL%20season">2019 NRL season</a> for the <a href="St.%20George%20Illawarra%20Dragons">St. George Illawarra Dragons</a> against <a href="South%20Sydney%20Rabbitohs">South Sydney</a>, starting on the wing and scoring two tries in their 20–16 loss in the last minute due to <a href="Campbell%20Graham">Campbell Graham</a> try at <a href="ANZ%20Stadium">ANZ Stadium</a>.
2020.
In August 2020, <a href="Sporting%20News">Sporting News</a> reported that Saab had sought an early release from his contract due to the traveling distance between <a href="Wollongong">Wollongong</a> and his home in <a href="Western%20Sydney">Western Sydney</a>. However, <a href="St.%20George%20Illawarra">St. George Illawarra</a> refused this request unless the club would be compensated either by cash or player transfer. In September, there was speculation that Saab would be joining the <a href="Manly-Warringah%20Sea%20Eagles">Manly-Warringah Sea Eagles</a> as a trade for St. George junior <a href="Reuben%20Garrick">Reuben Garrick</a>.
Saab made only four appearances for St. George in the <a href="2020%20NRL%20season">2020 NRL season</a> as the club finished 13th on the table.
On 26 November 2020, Saab was granted a release from his contract with St. George and shortly thereafter signed a three-year deal with Manly-Warringah.
2021.
In round 1 of the <a href="2021%20NRL%20season">2021 NRL season</a>, Saab made his debut for Manly-Warringah in the club's 46-4 loss against the <a href="Sydney%20Roosters">Sydney Roosters</a>.
In round 6 of the <a href="2021%20NRL%20season">2021 NRL season</a>, he scored two tries in Manly's 36-0 victory over the Gold Coast.
In round 9 of the <a href="2021%20NRL%20season">2021 NRL season</a>, Saab scored a <a href="hat-trick">hat-trick</a> in Manly's 38-32 victory over <a href="New%20Zealand%20Warriors">New Zealand Warriors</a>.
In round 10 of the <a href="2021%20NRL%20season">2021 NRL season</a>, Saab scored another two tries for Manly-Warringah in a 50-6 victory over Brisbane at <a href="Suncorp%20Stadium">Suncorp Stadium</a>.
In round 15, Saab scored two tries for Manly in a 56-24 victory over the <a href="Gold%20Coast%20Titans">Gold Coast</a>.
The following week, he scored a <a href="hat-trick">hat-trick</a> in Manly's 66-0 victory over <a href="Canterbury-Bankstown%20Bulldogs">Canterbury</a>.
In round 20, Saab scored two tries for Manly in their 40-22 victory over rivals Cronulla in the battle of the beaches match.
At the end of year club awards night, Jason Saab and <a href="Josh%20Schuster">Josh Schuster</a> were announced as joint winners of the <a href="Ken%20Arthurson">Ken Arthurson</a> Rising Star Award for 2021 after their strong seasons for Manly.
